topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Adam frames onboarding as the only universally-touched product surface and the first moment to deliver on brand promises. Lenny introduces Adam’s background (Lyft, Patreon, Imperfect Foods) and previews the episode’s three focus areas.

topics.title: Sponsor Break: Coda and Linear
topics.summary: Lenny reads sponsor messages for Coda (all-in-one docs with templates) and Linear (modern issue tracking and product workflows).

topics.title: Adam’s career overview and current work
topics.summary: Adam gives a quick career recap and explains his current pillars: Reforge EIR/course creation, advising, and his newsletter (fishmanafnewsletter.com). They also discuss how to engage him for advising.

topics.title: Early Lyft memories and launch story
topics.summary: Adam shares a vivid memory of Lyft’s launch event: opening garage doors, driving a mustached car into the office, and serving a pink mustache cake.

topics.title: Super Pumped reflections and Joseph Gordon-Levitt
topics.summary: Adam reacts to Super Pumped as both painful and validating, recalling competitive dynamics with Uber. He also tells a story about interviewing with Joseph Gordon-Levitt while JGL was in full Travis Kalanick costume on set.

topics.title: Why Adam wrote the growth competency model
topics.summary: Adam explains the need for a canonical framework for hiring/evaluating growth talent and avoiding shallow pattern-matching (“find another Adam”). He shares a cautionary tale from Wyzant where founders sought a “silver bullet” rather than a durable growth system.

topics.title: Model overview: four competency buckets
topics.summary: Adam outlines the four pillars—growth execution, customer knowledge, growth strategy, and communication/influence—and emphasizes building a balanced team rather than a unicorn. They discuss using the model for alignment, interviewing, and performance feedback.

topics.title: Deep dive: customer knowledge and user psychology
topics.summary: Adam breaks down customer knowledge (data fluency, psychology, narrative/creative learning) and argues users arrive with emotional frames, not purely logical ones. Lenny connects this to the idea that research builds a customer model that then guides product decisions.

topics.title: Deep dive: growth strategy and influence skills
topics.summary: Adam covers growth strategy (loop modeling, capital allocation/forecasting, prioritization/roadmapping) and communication/influence (strategic comms, team leadership, stakeholder management). He notes these are advanced, learned over time, and critical for aligning growth with product craft.

topics.title: Hiring up-and-coming growth talent: what to prioritize
topics.summary: Adam advises that early growth hires should be strong in execution and customer knowledge, and that founders must invest in mentorship/advisors to avoid wasted effort. He shares examples: hiring Ben at Lyft (high execution/work ethic) and transitioning Sean at Patreon from marketing to growth PM.

topics.title: Internal transfers vs specialists (SEO/paid growth)
topics.summary: Adam generally prefers internal transfers for speed and fit, but recommends external “surgeon” specialists once a company has traction and needs deep channel expertise (e.g., SEO or paid).

topics.title: Sponsor Break: Eppo experimentation platform
topics.summary: Lenny reads an ad for Eppo, an A/B testing platform for modern growth teams with fast slicing, north-star metric support, and broad experimentation coverage.

topics.title: Onboarding as an underappreciated growth lever
topics.summary: Adam explains why onboarding matters: everyone touches it, it must match brand promise, and users are maximally motivated early on. He describes retention impacts (shifting curves 10–20 points) and a Patreon example where human-guided onboarding increased early creator revenue by ~25% and informed productized improvements.

topics.title: Opinionated defaults and conversion vs retention tradeoffs
topics.summary: They discuss productizing onboarding learnings via guardrails and “opinionated defaults” (e.g., tier/pricing recommendations), with Lenny sharing Airbnb’s analogous “smart defaults.” Adam notes that doing onboarding right can sometimes lower raw conversion while improving qualification and long-term retention, requiring careful tradeoff measurement.
